quotes: Qian was born in 1928 in Tianjin.
In 1942, he joined the Communist Party of China as a middle school student in Shanghai.
After studying in the former Soviet Union, he began his diplomatic career by working in the Chinese embassy in Moscow in 1955.
Qian was vice-foreign minister from 1982 to 1988 and minister from 1988 to 1998.
Qian was vice-foreign minister from 1982 to 1988 and minister from 1988 to 1998.
He was vice-premier of the State Council from 1993 and retired in 2003.
Qian was the first Chinese foreign minister to attend an ASEAN event, the 1991 ASEAN Foreign Ministers Meeting in Malaysia.
In 1996, Qian was appointed director of the Preparatory
Former vice-premier Qian Qichen, who was China's foreign minister for a decade, died on Tuesday night in Beijing, according to a statement from the central authority released on Wednesday.

organizations.name: Center of US Studies at Renmin University of China
quotes: Shi Yinhong, director of the Center of US Studies at Renmin University of China in Beijing, said Qian 'made great contributions to China's relations with the US, Russia and neighboring countries'.

organizations.name: China Institute of International Studies
quotes: Ruan Zongze, executive vice-president of the China Institute of International Studies, said Qian managed to improve China's relations with Western countries in the 1990s.

Qian was born in 1928 in Tianjin.
In 1942, he joined the Communist Party of China as a middle school student in Shanghai.
Early in his career, Qian worked at Shanghai's Ta Kung Pao, which is said to be the oldest Chinese language newspaper still in operation in China.
After studying in the former Soviet Union, he began his diplomatic career by working in the Chinese embassy in Moscow in 1955.
Qian later served as ambassador to Guinea and director-general of the foreign ministry's Information Department.
